newsitem.title: THAILAND: Jasmine says its foreign loans hedged.
newsitem.headline: Jasmine says its foreign loans hedged.

text.p: Thai telecommunication firm Jasmine International Plc said on Wednesday it would not be affected by the central bank's baht flotation as all its foreign loans were hedged.
In a filing to the Stock Exchange of Thailand, Jasmine said foreign currency-denominated loans by the company and its affiliates totalled $367 million.

The Bank of Thailand announced earlier that it intended a "managed float" of the Thai baht and said the value of the baht would be set by market forces instead of being pegged to a basket of currencies.
Analysts said the central bank's move to float the baht was a de facto devaluation.

In a separate statement, Thai Telephone and Telecommunication Plc, which is majority owned by Jasmine, said a partial portion of its foreign loans totalling $353 million had been hedged against foreign exchange risk.
Of total foreign loans, $200 million had been covered by the option with a financial institution, Thai Telephone said.
"Therefore, only $153 million loans would be affected by the central bank's move," it said.
